s.text: True, the owner-manager model, successful as it has been, is not the only possible model for success.
More than that, the lesson of Dell's success has been misunderstood.
More than that, the lesson of Dell's success has been misunderstood.
More than that, the lesson of Dell's success has been misunderstood.
True, the owner-manager model, successful as it has been, is not the only possible model for success.

But actually this is a relatively recent development in American business, and while the financial success of Michael Dell is a fine expression of the American dream, the lessons the business world has drawn from that success are less salutary.
More than that, the lesson of Dell's success has been misunderstood.
True, the owner-manager model, successful as it has been, is not the only possible model for success.

But actually this is a relatively recent development in American business, and while the financial success of Michael Dell is a fine expression of the American dream, the lessons the business world has drawn from that success are less salutary.
As a result, except for the media business, where many large companies are still owned by individuals or families, most powerful U.S. corporations have fit a particular model.

Of course, neither Dell nor Gates actually saw any of these hundreds of millions of dollars, since their gains were reaped entirely on paper in the form of sharp increases in the stock prices of both Dell and Microsoft.
Dell was not, however, the most tired CEO in the land that evening.
But it's more likely that Dell has been a great manager because he's been running a company that is, in some important sense, his.
Since Michael Dell has been a great manager and has made billions of dollars, corporations have imagined that he's been a great manager because he's made billions of dollars.

Dunlap, for his efforts in wrecking--that is, restructuring--corporations, is rewarded with huge chunks of options that he immediately exercises so he can pocket the cash, not so he can invest in the future of the company.

Dunlap, for his efforts in wrecking--that is, restructuring--corporations, is rewarded with huge chunks of options that he immediately exercises so he can pocket the cash, not so he can invest in the future of the company.

The curious phenomenon that Dell's and Gates' enormous wealth points to is a resurgence in American business of what's often called "proprietary capitalism"--a system in which the people who run corporations are also the people who own them.

The curious phenomenon that Dell's and Gates' enormous wealth points to is a resurgence in American business of what's often called "proprietary capitalism"--a system in which the people who run corporations are also the people who own them.

There were always exceptions to this reign of the managers, to be sure, including Ford, where the Ford family kept tight control at least through the end of World War II; IBM, which was run by founder Thomas Watson and his son for most of the century; and DuPont.
